election_record.label: Vermont 1812 Governor

overview.note: The Official Results list Jonas Galusha with 19223 votes and Martin Chittenden with 15959 votes but the county totals add up to 19241 for Galusha and 15978 for Chittenden.

The Washingtonian (Windsor, VT), October 19, The Rutland Vermont Herald (Rutland, VT), October 14, The Democratic Republican (Walpole, NH), October 21, The Pittsfield Sun (Pittsfield, MA), October 22, and the True American (Trenton, NJ), October 26, report 19158 votes for Jonas Galusha and 15950 for Martin Chittenden.

The Centinel (Burlington, VT), September 10: "The election in this state exceeds the most sanguine calculation of the friends of our government. By this, our enemies may learn, Vermont is not so easily cheated out of her constituted liberties by designing men; even secret societies and dark designs only awaken their sense of danger and call forth their exertions, before slumbering in indifference, to rally round their constituted rights with a cement sufficiently efficatious for every centrifugal alienation. We have not been able to obtain any correct information from the counties of Bennington and Windham.--From the other counties in the state, we have obtained, as we think, a correct statement of the representatives, which gives the majority of 49 republicans. The votes for governor, as far as we have been able to obtain them, gives gov. Galusha 1102 nett gain over last year, of these the County of Windsor gives 361. Our Vermont blackguard seems to be very unfortunate in gaining proselytes in his county."

The Rutland Vermont Herald (Rutland, VT), September 9: "VERMONT ELECTION! Tuesday the first inst. being the constitutional period for electing a Governor, Lieut. Governor, Treasurer and twelve Councillors, to wield the destinies of this state for the ensuing year, the freemen, not unmindful of the important crisis, came forward in the full majesty of their strength, and the result is as we predicted, honorable to themselves, and glorious to their beloved country. The republican ticket has succeeded by an astonishing increased majority, for Governor, Lieut. Governor and Coucillors. The majority will be between THREE and FOUR THOUSAND! last year it was about 2000. In the House of Representatives there will be at least THIRTY majority."

The Pittsfield Sun (Pittsfield, MA), October 22: "We have great pleasure in laying before our readers the following extract of a letter to the Editor, from a gentleman high in office in Vermont, now at Montpelier. It will be seen, that the auspicious result of the Vermont Election has blasted the calculations of the Clintonian demagogues, as well as the Essex Junto, (who are cordial friends at this time) in obtaining Presidential Electors in that state, who might be subservient to their views. This, considering the disgraceful means which have been made use of to obtain their votes, must be highly gratifying to every real friend to the republican interest."

sub_unit.note: The Centinel (Burlington, VT), September 3: "The authority of the town of Burlington refused to receive the votes of a part of those freemen in the town whom they did not consider inhabitants of the town. They were received by W.C. Harrington Esqr." The refused votes are reported as 94 for Jonas Galusha and 10 for Martin Chittenden.

Wells, Frederick P. History of Newbury, Vermont. St. Johnsbury, VT: The Caledonian, 1902.
